snippet: The automaker is trying to fend off a rising tide of class-action lawsuits stemming from its recall of 2.6 million cars because of a dangerously defective ignition switch that it now links to 13 deaths.
abstract: General Motors will return to bankruptcy court as part of effort to shut down rising tide of class-action lawsuits stemming from its recall of 2.6 million vehicles; company will ask federal judge to enforce provision of its 2009 bankruptcy reorganization that insulated the new company from lawsuits related to accidents before that date; some experts say it might be a risky move.

byline.original: By HILARY STOUT and BILL VLASIC

lead_paragraph: The automaker is trying to fend off a rising tide of class-action lawsuits stemming from its recall of 2.6 million cars because of a dangerously defective ignition switch that it now links to 13 deaths.

headline.main: Hoping to Fend Off Suits, G.M. Is to Return to Bankruptcy Court
headline.print_headline: Hoping to Fend Off Suits, G.M. to Return to Bankruptcy Court
